channel.title: NTM overview on ntmscope
channel.description: Recent content in NTM overview on ntmscope

item.description:
M. avium complex

M. avium complex (MAC) consists of several species, the most important ones being M. avium, M. intracellulare and M. chimaera cit. They are all slow gowing mycobacteria (SGM) with different ranges of pathogenicity cit. IN the past, this complex was designated as M. avium-intracellulare complex (MAI) Cit. As several additional species have entered the complex, the term MAC is currently preferred cit.

M. avium

  • M. avium subsp. avium
  • M. avium subsp. silvaticum
  • M. avium subsp. hominissuis
  • M. avium subsp. paratuberculosis

M. avium subsp. avium

  • avian tuberculosis

M. avium subsp. silvaticum

-avian tuberculosis

M. avium subsp. hominissuis

  • NTM PD in humans
  • infections of pigs as well

M. avium subsp. paratuberculosis

  • cause of paratuberculosis in cattle
  • phylogenetically distinct

M. intracellulare

  • M. intracellulare
  • M. intracullulare subsp. chimaera

M. chimaera (M. intracellulare subsp. chimaera)

  • NTM-PD
  • heater cooler units
  • subspecies of M. intracellulare

M. yongoense

M. scrofulaceum

Mycobacterium genavense

Etymology

The term genavense is derived from the swiss city Geneva, where the bacterium was firstly isolated from a case series of HIV patients with a highly immunocompromised state cit.

Microbiology

M. genavense is a slow-growing mycobacterium that has a predilection for the gastgrointestinal tract cit. Its cultivation is fastiduous and classic solid culture media for mycobacteria remain negative quite often cit.

Epidemiology

Infections due to M. genavense are quite rare. A recent meta-anlysis could summarize XXX cases in HIV positive and negative individuals cit. Mainly cases were described in Europe, but the bacterium seems to be distributed across the whole world cit.

Clinical Manifestations

  • disseminated infections

Treatment

  • a macrolide containing regimen
